headline.main: 5 Tufts Students Go on Hunger Strike Over Janitor Layoffs
headline.print_headline: 5 Tufts Students Go on Hunger Strike Over Janitor Layoffs

docs.snippet: Five students at Tufts University have begun a hunger strike over plans to cut about 35 janitorial jobs at the end of May....
docs.lead_paragraph: Five students at Tufts University have begun a hunger strike over plans to cut about 35 janitorial jobs at the end of May.

headline.main: China's Economy Seen Slowing to 6.8 Percent in Q2-State Think Tank
headline.print_headline: China's Economy Seen Slowing to 6.8 Percent in Q2-State Think Tank

docs.snippet: China's economy is expected to slow further to 6.8 percent in the second quarter from a six-year low hit in the first, a top government think tank said in a research report that underscored the need for more stimulus to shore up faltering growth....
docs.lead_paragraph: China's economy is expected to slow further to 6.8 percent in the second quarter from a six-year low hit in the first, a top government think tank said in a research report that underscored the need for more stimulus to shore up faltering growth.

headline.main: Senate Panel Raises Privacy Concerns in White House Hacking Incident
headline.print_headline: Senate Panel Raises Privacy Concerns in White House Hacking Incident

docs.snippet: The U.S. Senate Commerce Committee has written President Barack Obama over concerns that a recently reported data breach on the White House computer system might have compromised the personal information of many Americans....
docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Senate Commerce Committee has written President Barack Obama over concerns that a recently reported data breach on the White House computer system might have compromised the personal information of many Americans.

docs.snippet: RUBIN--LeRoy, died May 2, 2015 at home in Manhattan of natural causes. He was 90 years old. Born in Bronx, NY on November 13, 1924, LeRoy was the son of Aaron and Dorothy Rubin and brother to Justine Auerbach, who predeceased him. He was married f...
docs.lead_paragraph:
RUBIN--LeRoy,

died May 2, 2015 at home in Manhattan of natural causes. He was 90 years old. Born in Bronx, NY on November 13, 1924, LeRoy was the son of Aaron and Dorothy Rubin and brother to Justine Auerbach, who predeceased him. He was married for 63 years to Barbara Eydenberg Rubin who survives him. They have three children-Jim Rubin (Faye Weitzman), Jane Hoffman (Coley) and Patty Sacks (Douglas), 11 grandchildren (Alexis (Evan), Zac, Josh, Danny, Sophie, Hillary, Tim, Chris, Olivia, Elizabeth and Haley), one great-grandchild (Myles), one nephew and three nieces. Lee was the founder and owner of LeeBar Management Company. Leebar owns and manages a variety of residential, commercial, and industrial properties both in and around New York and in other parts of the country. Lee converted numerous prewar apartment buildings on the upper westside into cooperatives, and loved to tell stories of his great bargaining accomplishments with the tenants groups in these buildings. Lee loved the business and remained until his death a very savvy bargain seeker and indefatigable deal hunter. He was an active board member of the Paul Taylor Dance Company and the President's Council at Weill Cornell Hospital. Lee was a long standing member and director of the Lotos Club. A hearty club participant, he served on the finance and arts committee. He was often found at state dinners, reading plays, and engaging with great interest in history book groups. Lee was known for a quick wit and irreverent sense of humor that often entertained and sometimes offended. He was an elegant man, a dapper dresser and loved conversation. Leroy graduated from Dewitt Clinton High School and the University of Pennsylvania. His college years were interrupted by his service in the US Army as a member of the 103rd Infantry Division in World War II. After basic training he was deployed to France but was soon captured by the Germans. He spent months in a POW camp in the Czech Republic. His wartime experiences - which influenced much of his adult life - were documented both by the Shoah foundation and the book, No Hero, No Coward, by George Davis. Above all, Lee cherished time with family, his adored wife, and their active life in the community of Stamford, Connecticut where he sat on school and museum boards. His quiet time was spent in the out of doors, on the ski slopes of Vermont, Colorado and Europe, fox hunting and horseback riding in Upper Westchester and with a great book. Lee remained to the end a patriarch and embracer of family time. He was an impulsive and persistent telephoner of his three children, their spouses and the 11 grandchildren. Lee, Dad, Grandpa, Great-gramps, Uncle Lee will be sorely missed but will live on in the family members he touched and deeply influenced. Rest well, Le Roi- our king! Our hearts are broken. The family will receive guests Monday and Tuesday from 4-8pm at 35 Sutton Place #9C. Contributions can be made to The Paul Taylor Dance Foundation, 551 Grand Street, New York, NY 10002 or The Lotos Club Foundation, 5 E. 66th Street, New York, NY 10065.

docs.lead_paragraph:
STAUTBERG--Aubrey.

I will miss you Ted, a warm and courageous friend and a gentleman to the core. You were admired by everyone you knew and for good reason. Most Sincerely, Joel I. Berson

docs.snippet: KOUSI--John D., long time resident of New York City died on April 4 in Malibu, CA. from complications of quadriplegia. John was born in Bay Shore long Island on January 21, 1934. He graduated from Yale University and New York University Law school...
docs.lead_paragraph: KOUSI--John D., long time resident of New York City died on April 4 in Malibu, CA. from complications of quadriplegia. John was born in Bay Shore long Island on January 21, 1934. He graduated from Yale University and New York University Law school and began his career practicing corporate law at Lovejoy Wasson Lundrgren and Ashton in New York City. He served as President of Fairfield International, a ship- owning firm, for 14 years. In 1987 he was one of the founding shareholders of Eastwind Maritime, an international shipping firm that came to own and operate dry bulk carriers, refrigerated ships, oil tankers, and container- ships. Following his retirement he remained involved for the rest of his life with private investments in international shipping. He will be so missed by his wife Elizabeth Easter Kousi, his wife of 50 years and their daughters, Christina Kousi Dobbs of London, England and Katherine Kousi of Malibu, CA. and his six grandsons - Conway Dobbs, Sinclair Dobbs, Ossian Dobbs, Aidan Flanigan, Truman Flanigan and Fergus Flanigan.
